The Gentlemen's Express
The Gentlemen's Code Commission has passed its
first obstacle and now faces its major test; it must be
approved by the student body. However, several of our
campus legislators have apparently become too
enamoured of their newest hobby, railroading, and in
their enthusiasm have forgotten their basic and overriding responsibility to the student body.
The proposed Commission can only be of use to
Hopkins if it is understood and approved by the majority of students. The Student Council has no right to
try to force this Commission upon the undergraduate.
The SC is not entitled to insure its passage by slanting
its presentation or its meaning. If the SC should succeed in forcing the passage of this constitutional amendment, it can only serve to add an unwarranted and unpopular appendage to the already befuddled organization
of student government.
This is not to say that the Gentlemen's Code Commission does not deserve passage by the students. It is
merely to point out that the Student Council should
take every possible step to insure that the students are
properly informed as to the content of the amendment
and that they be exposed to all arguments concerning
its passage.
It appears that Bob Abernethy and his supporters
in their desire to pass the amendment have neglected
their responsibility to the undergraduate. The assembly
concerning this issue should be organized in such a
manner that every side may be heard and questions
asked. To deny cross-questioning on the grounds that
the proponents of the measure are insufficiently eloquent seems a poor reason. The students are entitled to
a true debate of this issue in which no favoritism is
shown. Similarly, this debate should be scheduled so
that the maximum number of students are free to attend.

Equalify In Grading
The institution of a point system of grading would
eliminate, to a degree, certain of the inequalities and
inadequacies of the present system. That is, a 1 to
10 gradation as used at Harvard, or finer gradations of
the present 0 to 5 system now used, would enable instructors to make their reports more accurately and
fairly.
The current system, under which the "plus" and
"minus" portion of the grades are ignored when transcripts are prepared, makes no distinction between what
could be very different grades. Hence, a B- grade could
be a talked up C plus, while a B plus could be very close
to an A-. But both grades appear on the transcript as
B. Clearly, if a professor feels competent enough to
assign a grade more specific than just A, B, or C, then
the registrar should take the trouble to recognize it.

The Divided Campus
We note that the Hopkins campus has been divided
into and East and West zone by barbed wire fencing.
Although this is designed to facilitate the construction

The Gentlemen's Express
The Gentlemen's Code Commission has passed its
first obstacle and now faces its major test; it must be
approved by the student body. However, several of our
campus legislators have apparently become too
enamoured of their newest hobby, railroading, and in
their enthusiasm have forgotten their basic and overriding responsibility to the student body.
The proposed Commission can only be of use to
Hopkins if it is understood and approved by the majority of students. The Student Council has no right to
try to force this Commission upon the undergraduate.
The SC is not entitled to insure its passage by slanting
its presentation or its meaning. If the SC should succeed in forcing the passage of this constitutional amendment, it can only serve to add an unwarranted and unpopular appendage to the already befuddled organization
of student government.
This is not to say that the Gentlemen's Code Commission does not deserve passage by the students. It is
merely to point out that the Student Council should
take every possible step to insure that the students are
properly informed as to the content of the amendment
and that they be exposed to all arguments concerning
its passage.
It appears that Bob Abernethy and his supporters
in their desire to pass the amendment have neglected
their responsibility to the undergraduate. The assembly
concerning this issue should be organized in such a
manner that every side may be heard and questions
asked. To deny cross-questioning on the grounds that
the proponents of the measure are insufficiently eloquent seems a poor reason. The students are entitled to
a true debate of this issue in which no favoritism is
shown. Similarly, this debate should be scheduled so
that the maximum number of students are free to attend.

Equalify In Grading
The institution of a point system of grading would
eliminate, to a degree, certain of the inequalities and
inadequacies of the present system. That is, a 1 to
10 gradation as used at Harvard, or finer gradations of
the present 0 to 5 system now used, would enable instructors to make their reports more accurately and
fairly.
The current system, under which the "plus" and
"minus" portion of the grades are ignored when transcripts are prepared, makes no distinction between what
could be very different grades. Hence, a B- grade could
be a talked up C plus, while a B plus could be very close
to an A-. But both grades appear on the transcript as
B. Clearly, if a professor feels competent enough to
assign a grade more specific than just A, B, or C, then
the registrar should take the trouble to recognize it.

The Divided Campus
We note that the Hopkins campus has been divided
into and East and West zone by barbed wire fencing.
Although this is designed to facilitate the construction
of the new Roland wing, we wonder whether formal
rights of access have yet to be fixed. In particular we
wish to know where passports may be obtained so that
various users of the Barn can cross the line into the
West Sector in order to eat lunch or dinner at Levering.
Perhaps the H4U Committee could look into this
problem.

that the administration has recognized the need for a
student union and has its construction down on the
master plan for sometime after 1986.
